item.title: By: Justin Dearing
item.dc:creator: Justin Dearing
item.content:encoded:
Jes,

If linkedin is facebook for professionals, then its best use for me is “professional facebook stalking.”

I use facebook in terms of friending my coworkers on it, as well as clients. However, that’s administrata as far as I’m concerned, it has no intrinsic value. The value is when I’m about to get on a call I look the people on the outlook invite in linkedin. Are they employees or consultants? Does their experience list say technologists, or business oriented. Am I second or third degree from them, and through who? That way, if they prove to be difficult to work with on the conference call, I know which of my coworkers to visit and say “just got off a call with $x, whats his/her deal?!”

I also hope people do the same with me. I’m in more of a client facing position these days in a pretty much 100% Microsoft shop. However, personally I’m all over the map in terms of platforms used and have been very heads down in the past. If a client wants to interface with our software with as IBMi (AS/400) for example, I’d hope that the RPG dev on the first call would find my linkedin profile before the call, see that I started my career as a third shift iSeries operator, and know their not going to have to explain to me what a greenscreen is.
